headline: Why Alphabet Stock Ticked Higher Today
summary: CEO Sundar Pichai emphasized the company's commitment to developing AI.  On the back of encouraging pronouncements about its ever-deepening involvement with artificial intelligence (AI), Alphabet's (NASDAQ: GOOG)(NASDAQ: GOOGL) two listed stocks both gained ground on Friday.  The pair each rose in excess of 1% following CEO Sundar Pichai's remarks on where the company stands with AI.

headline: OpenAI to help UAE develop one of world's biggest data centers, Bloomberg News reports
summary: The ChatGPT maker is expected to be one of the primary anchor tenants for a 5-gigawatt data center campus in Abu Dhabi, the report said, citing people familiar with the matter.  The UAE and the United States on Thursday signed an agreement for the Gulf country to build the largest AI campus outside the U.S.

headline: Why CoreWeave Rocketed as High as 26% Today
summary: CoreWeave received additional price target hikes from Wall Street analysts following its Wednesday earnings report.  Furthermore, an SEC filing last night revealed Nvidia has increased its stake in the company, now worth $1.9 billion as of this writing.  Shares of artificial intelligence (AI) "neocloud" company and recent IPO CoreWeave (NASDAQ: CRWV) rocketed higher Friday morning, increasing as much as 26.3% on the day, before settling into a 22.5% gain as of 1:15 p.m. ET.

headline: Nvidia customers will push into AI until they 'become irrelevant'
summary: While the Magnificent Seven tech leaders continue to rally this week, artificial intelligence continues to be a core driver of growth within the tech space. Bokeh Capital Partners Founder and Chief Investment Officer Kimberly Forrest comes on the Morning Brief to talk more about the sustainability of the AI trade — namely in key players like Nvidia (NVDA) — and whether momentum behind trader enthusiasm can hold. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Morning Brief here.

headline: Long-running EU antitrust case of Microsoft Teams appears to be nearing an end
summary: European Union regulators will seek public comment on proposed changes from Microsoft for Teams, signaling the U.S. company may be nearing the end of a long-running antitrust case targeting its messaging and videoconferencing app.  Microsoft had previously offered some modifications including unbundling Teams from its Office software suite in an attempt to head off the antitrust probe shortly after it was opened by the EU two years ago.  The Commission said Friday that it will now seek feedback on fresh commitments Microsoft has made to resolve the competition worries.

raw.headline: Long-running EU antitrust case of Microsoft Teams appears to be nearing an end
raw.summary: European Union regulators will seek public comment on proposed changes from Microsoft for Teams, signaling the U.S. company may be nearing the end of a long-running antitrust case targeting its messaging and videoconferencing app.  Microsoft had previously offered some modifications including unbundling Teams from its Office software suite in an attempt to head off the antitrust probe shortly after it was opened by the EU two years ago.  The Commission said Friday that it will now seek feedback on fresh commitments Microsoft has made to resolve the competition worries.

headline: Microsoft makes Office-Teams offer to avert EU antitrust fine
summary: BRUSSELS (Reuters) -Microsoft has offered to make its Office product without Teams cheaper than when sold with Teams, EU antitrust regulators said on Friday, which could spare the company a big fine and ease tensions with the United States.  The European Commission said it would seek feedback from rivals and customers before deciding whether to accept the offer.  Microsoft's Vice President for European Government Affairs Nanna-Louise Linde said in a blogpost the proposal was a clear and complete resolution to concerns raised by rivals and would give Europeans more choice.

raw.headline: Microsoft makes Office-Teams offer to avert EU antitrust fine
raw.summary: BRUSSELS (Reuters) -Microsoft has offered to make its Office product without Teams cheaper than when sold with Teams, EU antitrust regulators said on Friday, which could spare the company a big fine and ease tensions with the United States.  The European Commission said it would seek feedback from rivals and customers before deciding whether to accept the offer.  Microsoft's Vice President for European Government Affairs Nanna-Louise Linde said in a blogpost the proposal was a clear and complete resolution to concerns raised by rivals and would give Europeans more choice.

headline: Should You Buy Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) Stock After Its 47% Drop?
summary: AMD is racing to catch up to Nvidia in the market for AI chips for the data center.  It has won over top Nvidia customers with its MI300X AI chip, and will soon ship a new version.  Advanced Micro Devices (NASDAQ: AMD) supplies some of the best chips in the world for computers, cars, game consoles, and data centers.
